-O5VUuGJg02q35KrI2lz.content:
\*note: The contents of this website are mine and do not reflect any position of the U.S. government or the Peace Corps.\* About three months ago, I was coming off the high of my college graduation, holding a computer science degree in one hand and an acceptance letter to a master's program in another. Now, I'm in the middle of rural Paraguay, fresh off a bout of food poisoning and nursing a broken foot.

A few weeks after graduation, I traded my cap in gown in for the "hardest job you'll ever love" as a Peace Corps Volunteer. While some might say my altruism has gotten the best of me, one thing is for certain: I'm still a computer scientist / software engineer at heart. As such, I've elected to try and document some of my journey in the Peace Corps through this blog that I made from scratch (hence why things sometimes looks like crap, so forgive the design and spelling mistakes). With it, I hope to show my parents (and the world) I'm still alive, stave off occasional hours of bordem, and keep my coding skils from atrophying. Anyways, back to the broken foot thing. It all started when Grace and I arrived as Peace Corps (PC) Health Volunteers in Paraguay. We arrived in-country around May 29th after a short stint of training in Washington D.C. At the airport in Asuncion, we were immediately greeted by some awesome PC staff and whisked to a nearby hotel. Looking out the fogged-up windows of the PC van, let's just say I could tell we weren't in (Ar)kansas anymore.

We spent a few days in the hotel "easing in" to Paraguayan culture and getting briefed on a variety of PC protocols and expectations. Off hours were filled with card games, goofy photos, chess, or mini adventures outside of the hotel to get a "lay of the land". Surprisingly, despite coming from many walks of life and parts of the U.S., all the volunteers hit it off really well!

After a few days of getting briefed in the hotel, volunteers were quickly matched with and shipped off to host families. Fortunately, Grace and I hit it off with our host parents almost immediately (not to brag, but probably on account of the insaaaaane magic card trick I showed them when we first met). Over the course of the next month, we spent evenings watching movies (or possum fights), playing othello, making alfajores / chipa, chowing down on mandioca (the starch staple of Paraguay), or laughing as Ciri (our host dad) taught me funny Guarani phrases like chivivi. Life as a volunteer was pretty solid -- that is, until tragedy (or rather, a mango) struck.

Cutting to the chase here, I broke my foot halfway through pre-service training while I was playing f√∫tbol with some other PCVs after a long day of training. I don't exactly know if slick grass or an errant mango is to blame, but either way, it's gonna be tough to beat the Wiley Coyote allegations. \*Note to self: only play f√∫tbol in cleats from now on, and beware of mangos!\*

The break was bad enough that the PC docs said I needed to get surgery -- it was just a matter of whether I'd receive care back in Arkansas or in Paraguay. If I chose to go home, given PC's 40-day recovery policy, it was unlikely I would be able to return. I'd be lying if I said this wasn't a nailbiting decision, but then I realized I'm living in a country with pro soccer players. Armed with that knowledge, I went ahead and opted to have my surgery in Paraguay. With that decision, just a week after breaking my foot, I was under the knife. Obviously, I survived!

Although breaking a foot has indeed sucked (0/10, wouldn't recommend), recovery has felt like a relative walk in the park (er, hobble I guess). PC staff has been more than accomodating, doing everything in their power to make sure I'm included in activities and can get around Paraguay with a set of crutches. What's more, a broken foot has proved to be the ultimate conversation starter with locals! My favorite response to inquiries as to what happened is simply "estuve jugando f√∫tbol con Messi".

As I write this, it seems the worst of this broken foot fiasco is behind me. I can't run, but I'm already back to walking (albeit, slowly)! Community integration has also been going great, though I'd be remiss to not mention it would be better if I could play f√∫tbol :(. Luckily, I don't need two feet to play violin -- a fact I've been taking advantage of.

Alas, this chapter of my blog comes to a close. In the future, I'll aim to write a little more frequently, but until then, here's a sporadic list of stuff that didn't make the cut this first time around but I still want to remember in the future: Maxita fleas, week alone in Asuncion, grabbing sugar cane juice with Andres, karaoke and stairs on crutches, piiiiiiines in class with Charlie, teaching Pablo(?) a magic trick, Ciri's f√∫tbol matches, broken steering column, funny farts at the huerta, deferral to GTECH, A/C classes in community, crazy epidural. Anyways, until next time, jajotopata!
-O5VUuGJg02q35KrI2lz.title: A Jopara of Broken Bones, Magic Tricks, and Mandioca

-O7W7SPUuJYJJXa9S2Eh.title: Building a Neural Network from "Scratch" Part 1: Simple Linear Regression

-O9UwhBY1xxjixv_4N9B.content:
\*note: The content of this website is mine alone and does not reflect the views of the U.S. Government, the Peace Corps, or the Paraguayan Government.\* Grace and I have been in site for a little over two month now, and we just had our site presentations! The school district superintendents came in clutch and let us use their projector, and the screen that a professor at the colegio set up for us looked fantastic. The turnout was great, and I'm pretty sure everyone liked the cake we served -- it had dulce de leche, so what's not to like?

With our site presentation out of the way and a few months of charlas & integration under our belts, Grace and I are more than ready to hit the ground running with some projects. We've already lined up charlas for breast cancer awareness, reserved a classroom for our weekly English class (we just had our first class!), and coordinated dates/times with the directora of our colegio to conduct some clubs!

Backtracking a little bit here, things have been pretty great in Grace's and my community, especially since my foot is (almost) healed. Now, I'm actually able to play sports, even if that just means hobbling around as the goalie in f√∫tbol or jumping an inch off the ground during volleyball. Things haven't been all play and no work though -- Grace and I have also been able to help facilitate a couple charlas with a psychologist and the health agents in our community.

Practically everyone we've come into contact with has been super guapo, from the directoras of colegios/escuelas to attendants of nearby shops. Grace and I got bikes a few weeks back, so it has been awesome to ride around and visit places and people we haven't seen before. It's also nice to have a quicker route to the houses that sell ice cream and empanadas üòã. Our host family has been especially great! We've been to a baptism, a liqueur festival, a family reunion, and a few birthday parties already, so we definitely feel like we're "part of the family"! Our host sister is a lawyer and our host brother is a bacteriologist, so dinner conversations are always pretty interesting (at least as interesting as they can get with my weak Spanish vocabulary). Grace and I have also had a blast playing cards, chess, Jenga, and Othello with our host niece.

Cuisine here has definitely been a bit more "adventurous" then what I'm used to in the U.S though. Liver and tripe have been on the menu a few times, and on one occasion, we had an asado with cabeza de chancho (pig head). Most of the chancho was pretty delicious, but I think I'll pass on the brain next time. Grace says I'm just being "picky", but I don't know -- I think I just prefer flavors that are a little less... intelligent üß†. I'm still the guy to "try anything once", but after this experience, vegetarianism is looking quite enticing!

In other news, Grace and I finally found a house to rent! There were a few hoops we had to jump through to get things finalized for it, but it looks like we'll have our own spot for the duration of our service. A huge plus is the plants we have behind the house -- we've got a mango tree, an avocado tree, and lime tree! Looks like we're gonna have a pretty awesome Christmas when these bad boys ripen. We just moved in, which isn't saying much considering 1) we don't own that much stuff and 2) we only moved two doors down from our host family. Regardless, Grace and I are excited to be in our own space to make non-instant coffee and have more control over our schedules. Grace is going to have to have a stricter routine now that she's a pro soccer player.

That's all for now. Signing off, here are some bonus photos and a sporadic list of things I don't have time to mention but still want to put in here: mucho aire, penales with C., eating roadkill, empanadas with Zulma, clutch disks in Yegros, Gavin visit & "corgified" dogs, building tin roofs with host dad, bike seat butt, teaching Ever chess, Grace's soccer game, teaching go-fish and AI to A/C class, tatu confusion.
-O9UwhBY1xxjixv_4N9B.title: Cabeza de Chancho!?!

-ODOVn6wggD4S5ID53b-.content:
*note: The content of this website is mine alone and does not reflect the views of the U.S. Government, the Peace Corps, or the Paraguayan Government.* It's been about 6 months since Grace and I touched down in Paraguy, and summer is unmistakably in full swing (I'm literally sweating as I write this). While I've still got a lot to learn as far as Spanish, Guaran√≠, and Paraguayan culture go, there's one thing I've learned for sure: bugs south of the equator ain't no joke! I found out the hard way that we've got some big 'ol cockroaches living in our ceiling (one of which "dropped in" on my head a few weeks back), and it's clear that the spiders down here definitely eat their wheaties.

Filling in some gaps a bit since my last post, Grace and I have been living in our house for around 2ish months now, and we couldn't be happier with it. We have running water, a slow internet connection, and A/C, so we definitely fall on the "Posh Corps" side of the site spectrum (bless the souls of the volunteers that grapple with "compost toilets" üôè). Afternoons are long and hot, but a cold guampa of terer√© with a friend makes time fly by. Although we don't live with our host family anymore, we still see them pretty often. Whether we're passing by on the way to our USF, buying groceries, or sharing a Sunday asado, we've had no shortage of opportunities to interact with them, and it's always a treat. Our host brother-in-law is attempting to learn English, and he often has questions that make me wonder what the creators of English were thinking.

About a month after moving in, we had another volunteer training. This time though, it was with our counterparts! We had some fun, shared some ideas, and crafted plans for the upcoming summer. All said and done, it was a blast cooking s'mores and playing soccer with our counterparts, and as an added bonus, we left with a plan for a summer camp in our community.

In other news, Grace and I now have a little guardian to help combat the crazy bugs down here -- we decided to get a cat! She's the color of pepper, so we decided to name here Paminta, which means "pepper" in Tagalog. She loves attacking our feet and peeing in our bathroom (ironically right next to the toilet), so she has been a bit of a handful. We love her nonetheless! To keep an eye on her when we leave the house, I went ahead and made a super rudimentary "kitty cam" with some spare stuff laying around the house -- security cameras are waaaaaaay too pricey down here.

With the school year over as of about a week ago, Grace and I have found ourselves with a bit more free-time than usual. We're relishing in it though -- after the new year, our hands will be pretty full with a summer camp, advanced English classes, zumba classes, a young engineers club, and (hopefully) community-organized movie nights. For now though, when we're not lending a hand prepping charlas or reports in our USF, we escape the heat and lean into our hobbies: Grace has her crochet, books, and kitty time, and I have my Advent of Code, side projects, and occasional ping pong and chess matches with a local (we bought ping pong paddles and a football in Asunci√≥n a few weeks back, both have been a hit).

I've also recently started Guaran√≠ classes with a local profesor. To be honest, I'm struggling a little bit -- I was pretty strong in Spanish class back in the states (ya know, when the class was English \<===> Spanish), but I'm quickly realizing it's pretty tough to learn a language through another language you're not entirely proficient in.

Bringing this blog to a close (and before I rattle off a sporadic list of things I want to remember), I'd be remiss if I didn't mention I got a haircut! Obviously, that's not all that interesting on its own, but the cool thing is that someone in the community offered to come to my house and cut my hair for free! Either my previous haircut was that bad, or my barber is just that welcoming of a guy -- I choose to believe the latter üòâ. Now, without further ado, here's said list and some photos: finessing some computers, FOP grant applications, teaching chess to F & T, ping pong with A y E, jumping spider, other PC couple, Wicked weekend, fused bike seat, almost bowling, and fixing a printer.
-ODOVn6wggD4S5ID53b-.title: Bugs, Beets, Battlestarga‚Äì I mean, Balls

-OFOEVR_mCpfXg8H5gro.content:
note: The content of this website is mine alone and does not reflect the views of the U.S. Government, the Peace Corps, or the Paraguayan Government. It's almost New Year's Eve, and it's clear that the Paraguayan climate has no plans to lay off the gas when it comes to heat. I visited a friend that's been here for about a year and a half (more on that in a sec), and he imparted the wisdom that it reaches over 117¬∞F here in January, even in the campo ... so 6d 76 62 79 20 73 6c 61 61 6c 79 20 6c 65 77 73 6c 61 70 63 6c 21 I guess.

It's been a bit of a slow roll through December since my last blog, but things haven't been totally uneventful. For one, I helped fix a local friend's computer. It was a really old Toshiba Satellite with a hard drive that made a few odd sounds on boot, then proceeded to shut down almost immediately. The computer technician my friend took it to said it would be impossible to fix, so giving it to me was a bit of a hail Mary before it got sent to the dump. I initially figured something funky was up with the arm of the hard drive or the boot record, but before I could investigate much more, the problem resolved itself after a hard reset (holding the power button for 15 seconds, removing the battery, turning back on, etc). I guess turning things off and back on again really is the answer sometimes!

Moving along, with the slowness in-site that accompanies the holidays, I decided to visit a buddy's "nearby" site to learn a bit about the projects he's been doing in his community for the past year and a half. "Nearby" is in quotes because, as the crow flies, his site is pretty close to mine. However, with bus hecticness down here, I ended up having to go all the way to Asunci√≥n, turning a 5ish hour journey to a 24ish hour one. All good -- I got to eat some Mexican food and visit a hobby electronics store while I was in town, so it was totally worth it.

My buddy is an engineer by training and one of the hardest working folks I've ever met. Impressively, he built his own gym from scratch at site! Though I didn't stay at his site long, we spent our time chatting with locals, looking at stars (no light pollution does wonders), grilling up burgers, and making homemade weight plates out of concrete and bicycle rims (he was expanding his gym and I wanted to see how he made his weights). Perhaps the coolest thing of all is that the weight plates were designed jointly by him and one of the community members. Role model: found!

Fast-forwarding a bit, Christmas here was a quiet yet enjoyable time. On Christmas Eve, Grace and I went over to our host family's house to enjoy a small asado as the clock struck midnight. I brought my violin to play a little Christmas music (of course!), and the family was thrilled enough with my performance that they invited us along to another house to continue playing. Feliz Navidad was obviously a crowd favorite, but I've been more partial to White Christmas as of late -- nothing like the heat to make you dream of one.

The tide of a new year inevitably brings in a few waves of reflection (or existentialism, have your pick). It's hard to believe Grace and I left the U.S. 6 months ago. Although it feels like the time has flown by, the missed holidays, life milestones of friend and family, and birthdays are stacking up. However, I'm glad to be where I am. Nestled between the cold sips in terere circles, ad-hoc ping-pong matches with locals, and hot afternoons people-watching at our health post, I've found a little bit of perspective on life, as well as a rekindled love for a few hobbies (I found time to actually complete the advent of code this year! üí™)

Cutting the corniness now, as always, here's that sporadic list of things I want to remember and a bonus picture: night shooting pool with GGTL, G leaving, mask lady on caca express, Schrodinger's (locked in) cat, finding Bernie, Jimmy the electronics man, jumping jack E, back with Jif, birthday call.

For those wondering what that weird string up top is, I ask: Et tu, Brute?. For those wondering what the rest of the info below means, you'll have to work a little harder to find out (hint: it was my birthday recently). FC CF 1D BB 80 9D DD 4B EC C2 9D 88 14 BF 9B CE D5 71 F3 D7 FB 86 15 B7 84 D5 CF 1D BB 8E D3 82 1A B0 D7 D1 8A 18 AA 82 CF 8A 08 D4 DA 9D A9 12 B0 9E CE 87 5B BD 85 C4 9F 0F B1 D7 DF 80 14 B5 FD 90 CF 3D B7 99 D4 9C 13 FE 93 D8 8A 0B FE 9B D8 8E 09 B0 9E D3 88 5B BC 98 D2 84 71 F3 D7 FB 86 15 B7 84 D5 CF 1A AA D7 D1 8A 1A AD 83 9D DC 5B 93 BE E9 CF 14 AE 92 D3 CF 18 B1 82 CF 9C 1E A9 96 CF 8A 5B B3 96 C9 87 5B BD 98 C8 9D 08 BB 84 B7 C2 5B 99 92 C9 CF 12 B0 83 D2 CF 1A B0 98 C9 87 1E AC D7 DA 9D 1A BA D7 CE 8C 13 B1 98 D1 CF 14 AE 83 D4 80 15 D4 DA 9D A9 12 B0 9E CE 87 5B B0 92 C8 9D 1A B2 D7 D3 8A 0F A9 98 CF 84 5B B8 85 D2 82 5B AD 94 CF 8E 0F BD 9F B7 C2 5B 99 92 C9 CF 0B AB 95 D1 86 08 B6 92 D9 D0 5B 8D 9F D2 80 0F F2 D7 C9 87 1A AA D7 D0 86 1C B6 83 9D 8D 1E FE 96 9D 9C 0F AC 92 C9 8C 13
-OFOEVR_mCpfXg8H5gro.title: "Broken" Computers and Dreaming of a White Christmas

-OJdDSdcGhE2j9y4GdkC.content:
note: The content of this website is mine alone and does not reflect the views of the U.S. Government, the Peace Corps, or the Paraguayan Government. cooler note: I added email notifications to my website! While in desktop view (sorry mobile users), click the bell icon in the top left of the blog feed and follow the prompts A common phrase in Peace Corps circles is "The days are long, but the months fly by". It's cornier than Kansas, but I guess that doesn't detract from the truth of it. It's hard to believe it's February, and that it's already been nearly 9 months since Grace and I last set foot on American soil. I guess the proof is in the pudding -- since we left, the U.S. elected & inaugurated a new president (Elon Musk), the AI war has gone into full swing with the release of the open-source model, DeepSeek, and I am severely out of the loop on what movies do and do not exist (wait, there's a movie with Deadpool and Wolverine now?!?) For New Year's, Grace and I went over to our host fam's house for a small celebration and asado. While things were pretty lowkey, it was definitely a bigger ordeal than Christmas. Our host parents' family and friends came from all over to enjoy a meal, and while the kids in the family played with small, presumably harmless (ü§û) firecrackers near presumably durable (ü§û) powerlines, Grace and I hung back with the adults to discuss intracacies of the English language, the different flavors of Coca Cola in other countries, and the subtle nuances in cultures we've encountered travelling around the world. Shortly after New Year's, Grace and I embarked on a brief journey to Iguazu Falls on the border of Argentina and Brazil. Fun fact: the name "Iguazu" is actually the Spanish spelling of "Yguazu", directly translating to "Big Water" in Guaran√≠!. We stayed in a cute, touristy little town called Puerto Iguazu on the Argentinian side of the falls. While things were exorbanintly expensive (my wallet is crying), everything was worth it once we feasted our eyes on "The Devil's Throat" waterfall: the crown jewel of the park, a good couple hundred feet taller than Niagra Falls.

"Magical" would be an understatement when describing the mystique of the park. Grace and I met up with a few volunteers while we were there and splurged on a speedboat ride that took us right up to (and under) the falls. It was like the Jungle Cruise at Disneyland on steroids -- more adrenaline, stunningly beautiful sights, and the subconcious knowledge that the caymans and canopies we saw weren't cheap fa√ßades of plaster and plastic, but rather the real thing.

Upon getting back to site, we kicked off our summer camp, English classes, computation/electronics class, and youth sports club. While things were a hair shakey at the start, it didn't take long for Grace and I to hit our stride. At this point, it's like clockwork -- we've been having English classes Monday and Friday, computation classes and summer camp on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and youth sports club meetings most evenings. Outside of that, when we're not planning our next set of classes and activities, we cool off in our hammocks or pass by our local USF to see if they need an extra hand with anything (making flyers, fixing computers, etc.).

In other news, while teaching one of our English classes, we came across a litter of 7 abandoned kittens! They were left in an engine beside the old train station where we teach our English classes, all hungry, filthy, and cute as hell. They couldn't have been more than a few weeks old, so Grace and I couldn't resist taking them in. Had we been privy to the weeks of bitten fingers, fleas, cacophonic cries, or stink that came with them, perhaps we would've hesitated a bit more in taking them in. I'm happy we did though; in the end, we found great homes for all of them (100% survival rate baby), one of which was with another volunteer in our cohort!

As I write this, summer is all but coming to an end. The ratio of school uniforms to stray cows we're seeing in the streets is growing little by little everyday, and daily temperatures are thankfully doing the opposite. This week, Grace and I are finishing up the last of our summer activities. Last week marked the end of our English classes, and this week marks the end of our computer class and summer camp. With hectic mornings and plans that fell apart day-of, this summer has been quite the rollercoaster! It's been exhausting, but it's the small things that make it worth it.

Bringing this blog to a close, I made a new friend recently! He's the same guy that cut my hair in the last blog, and his name is Alberto. We've been playing f√∫tbol, drinking terere, and playing rounds of pool lately (I found out a few days back that someone owns a small table in our community!). He's quite the jokester, and he's never afraid to give me a (much needed) Guaran√≠ lesson or (much needed) f√∫tbol advice.

Last but not least, here's a few bonus photos and a sporadic list of things I want to remember: pool with Trieu & due√±o, black tea and Socrates, venture to Will site & ice cubes on Rainbow, VR CD meeting, broken multimeter, wallet almost stolen in PI, pikmin bdays, A2 engage, monkey respect at the falls, fake valentine flowers, almost being a dog's dinner, wine & dine at lighthouse, dental charla numbers
-OJdDSdcGhE2j9y4GdkC.title: Big Water, Summer Camps, and Abandoned Kittens

-OOElMU8P3HOwZ5Eit2h.content:
note: The content of this website is mine alone and does not reflect the views of the U.S. Government, the Peace Corps, or the Paraguayan Government. Cold weather has finally arrived here in Paraguay, and it couldn't have come any sooner. As of late, Grace's and my electricity bill has been skyrocketting to Tres Kandu levels, so the cold weather brings a financial comfort in addition to a physical one. Shortly after the school year kicked off, Grace and I respun some of our summer activities to fit the new school-year schedule, and even added in a few new ones. At the moment, our general schedule in the afternoon involves going to the local pista and hosting a youth club meeting on Mondays, a "mini" summer camp for younger kids on Tuesdays, a guys' night and Zumba on Wednesday, a gals' night and exercise class on Thursdays, and "free-for-all" days on Fridays. While f√∫tbol is naturally a favorite activity, we've incrementally been introducing ultimate frisbee, American football, and ping pong. For the last one, I haven't lost yet, despite the efforts of some pretty motivated community members (sorry Alberto!). We've also started co-teaching a P.E. class every Thursday and Friday morning at our colegio and hosting free community movie nights every Saturday evening.

Since February, outside of continuing to work with youth and helping out in our USF (more on that later), Grace and I have gotten into the habit of going to the gym with our host brother. Serendipitously, we figured out that we can ride into town with our host brother and ride back to site with our USF doctor, avoiding the high bus fees that typicaly accompany the journey. It's an awesome arangement, and I'm happy to get back into going to the gym, but the catch is that we have to leave significantly before the buttcrack of dawn to do so...like, at 4:30AM...which means we've been having to wake up even before that üò¢. It's all good though -- Grace and I have made a routine of getting up around 3:45AM, making oatmeal & coffee, and trying to knock out the NY times crossword before shipping out. Naturally, our bedtime has been that of super old people -- we try to hit the hay by 9 at the latest.

On another note, I hinted at this in the last blog, but I've somewhat become the go-to "tech help" here in my community. I've helped fix slow / broken computers, wonky phones, and pesky printer problems pretty much from the first few weeks of getting here. However, that role might be coming to an end... I recently busted someone's 500Gb harddrive while trying to fix their computer. I know, I know, shameful. Long story short (techy talk incoming, skip if you don't care), someone's 15+ year old laptop in our USF was only booting into its OS about 10% of the time, so they gave it to me to take a look at it. I thought it might be a problem with the MBR on the hard drive, but even when I took it out, the device acted a little buggy when booting into the BIOS. Suspecting an outdated / messed up BIOS, I went ahead and tried to incrementaly update it using a spare flash drive with FlashDOS and the appropriate BIOS update file from Dell. All was going well, but while I was updating things, I accidentally knocked the hard drive I took out of the computer off my counter, sending it plumetting to my hard tile floors. I prayed to the computer gods that all was well (it wasn't a high drop, and the drive was powered off), but alas, the drive caught the click of death. With the computer pretty much damaged irreparably (as far as resources in Paraguay go), and my ego perhaps even more so, I went ahead and bought the busted computer at a premium. Ooof... still hurts like hell to think about.

Moving on, Semana Santa is coming to a close as a write this, and with it, so it seems are Grace's and my frequent gym seshes. Starting this week, our doctor will be on vacation for a while, meaning we won't have a ride to our community in the morning if we choose to go to the gym. As a result, our gym-going rythm will be taking a hiatus. It's a W for our sleep schedules, but an L for our gainz (üò¢). Fortunately, we've got a back-up plan: we've started building a gym for our community!

I enlisted the help of my buddy Erick from one of the previous blogs to help us build the plates, as well as the help of some community members to help me gather and refine the materials for building other components of the gym. Progress is steady; we've already got some plates squared away and one squat rack planted. We definitely still have our work cut out for us, but I'm at least happy to have a project that entails building something with my hands.

Grace and I currently are passing an evening in (cue Nacho Libre voice) Encarnaci√≥n to seek respite from an incredibily loud party that'll be going on till the wee hours of the morning next to our house. Come Monday, we'll be hitting the ground running with some math / reading initiatives for kids in the escuela, continuing work on the gym, and preparing a computer lab in our colegio (a super-awesome fellow volunteer clutched up and was able to bring some laptops to Paraguay from a Labdoo hub in Spain!). I already miss site, but it's nice to be somewhere different -- Encarnaci√≥n is a lovely little town, but I will say the chairs are a little too small for my liking.

Anyways, closing things out for real, as always, here are a few bonus photos and a list of things I want to remember: hombre-ara√±a on the roof with photographers, baby driver, Paraguayan pins (loud music apparently), Q. spirits, corny dog, spacing out with Interstellar, medical separation, Swiss-Paraguay coffee, meeting Pedro, walking through a dining room to climb, P.E. gaslighting, LOL jokes, y chipa-making.
-OOElMU8P3HOwZ5Eit2h.title: Early Mornings, (actually) Broken Computers, and Building a Gym

-OTEGn5fv0XPafOQbzFM.content:
note: The content of this website is mine alone and does not reflect the views of the U.S. Government, the Peace Corps, or the Paraguayan Government. I know, I know, it's been a hot second since I've written anything here. I'd love to chalk that up to being absurdly busy (which is perhaps a half-truth), but the reality is that I've simply preferred to spend my free time on chess.com instead of jacktnorris.dev as of late üòÇ. I got beat by a few volunteers at the start of service...and I took that personally.

In all seriousness though, I'll be better about writing more consistently in the future! For now, I'll go ahead and chronicle how the past couple months have went. Shortly after my last blog wrapped, Grace and I installed a weight stand for our community's outdoor gym with the help of few local kids. They insisted on helping (community-driven development for the win), and although it wasn't super Peace Corps health volunteery of me, I gave them a few (sugar-free) sodas for lending a helping hand.

Not too long after we installed the stand, Master Trainer Brian (Grace's and my boss) visited our site to assess if our community would be a good fit to host the incoming Peace Corps trainees for a few days. We showed him around, introduced him to some possible host families, and even enjoyed a bit of ice cream. In the end, he got a kick out of the "clapper" I installed in our house, and he was happy enough with his visit that Grace and I will be hosting some trainees come July!

A few days after MST Brian's visit, we caught a bus up north to explore the most rugged area of Paraguay: the Chaco. Backtracking a second here, a number of months ago, Grace and I befriended a missionary couple from the U.S that lived in a nearby pueblito -- a relationship that led to the occasional afternoon sharing a meal or some (non-instant üôå) coffee. That couple moved to the Chaco around the start of April, and they offered to host Grace and I for a few days if we made the trek up to visit. Chomping at the bit to see our friends again (and the legendary Chaco), we caught a 12 hour bus to Filadelfia, a Mennonite colony and gateway city to the Chaco. Upon arrival, our days were filled with museum and nature site visits, tasty food, (non-instant üôå) coffee, and board games. An added bonus was the laberinto vegetal , a corn-maze like labyrinth in the middle of nowhere that Grace and I raced to complete (at the request our missionary hosts). Not to brag...but ella comi√≥ mi polvo

After spending a few days in the Chaco (and seeing some really awesome birds), Grace and I said goodbye to our missionary friends and embarked on a journey to the Peace Corps training center for a few briefings. Grace and I (along with a couple other volunteers) will be preparing the incoming class of trainees for life and work in Paraguay, so Peace Corps set aside a few days to brief us before the new group's arrival. Seeing the training center again was a blast from the past, and it was a real treat to see some old friends.

Upon getting back to site, Grace and I continued with our projects as normal and finally opened up the community gym we've been working on to the public. At the moment, our main demographic is single moms and a handful of curious teens. However, as the gym grows to include some freeweights, a bench, and a bench rack, I'm hoping we can get a more marbled demographic.

Speaking of a bench rack, I once again enlisted the help of my buddy Sevelio (maestro of wood) to help me cut some wood. Upon arriving at his shop/house, in place of Sevelio, I was greeted by a man as verbose as Silent Bob, yet with a face as demonstrative as Jim Carrey's. Once Sevelio pulled up, I learned this mystery man was 1) Sevelio's wife's cousin, 2) an incredibly successfuly carpenter from Asunci√≥n, and 3) mute ever since childhood. Given we both spoke approximately the same amount of Guaran√≠, Sevelio's cousin and I hit it off pretty well, and I can confidently say he's probably one of the funniest people I've met in Paraguay! Physical comedy was his specialty, which is a pretty daring feat when you're working as a carpenter.

Sevelio gifted me some mandarinas and mandioca in return for cutting my wood (in typical, generous, Paraguayan fashion). However, despite living in Paraguay for a year, I had no clue how to prepare mandioca -- this was the first time I'd been gifted it fresh out of the ground. Grace had prepared it once with our host mom, but she was gone for the week helping out with PST. Too prideful to ask my host mom for help and get laughed it, I went ahead and called up my buddy and barber, Alberto. What ensued was a memorable evening of mandioca peeling, asaditos, and Soldados o Zombies, a tragically discontinued show on Amazon Prime.

Anyways, Grace just got back from her PST work a few days ago, and she arrived just in time to celebrate our host niece's first birthday! Paraguayans go hard in the paint when it comes to partying (even if it's just for a 1 year old), so Grace and I ended up having to turn in for the night long before the festivities actually ended. Regardless though, while we we were there, we had an awesome time celebrating with our host family. At this point, Grace and I have already passed the 1 year mark in our service. While I admit it hasn't felt like we've done a ton, retrospecting on the relationships we've built over the past year (both in and out of site) tells a different story--kids race to hug us when we stroll into the esceula, parents trustfully send their ni√±os to our events, and the teens and our community have warmed up to us drastically, with some of even the quietest ones coming to greet us in the streets. Countless community members have offered and contributed their time, tools, or resources for projects we have in the community. And of course, my Spanish is leagues better than it was when we first started our journey here.

Not to rest on these (small) laurels, Grace and I know the job is not finished -- we still have a few projects we'd like to get off the ground and running sustainably before the end of service, leveraging the relationships we've been able to build thus far. As to what those projects are...you'll just have to wait and see üòâ. Signing off, as always, here's that sporadic list I want to remember in addition to a few bonus photos: beach boys vacation with my parents, HORSE ankle, Chaco mosquitos, Nivacle visit, cured ears, duck ring toss, 3 / 1 = ? , pho double date, grapefruit haircut & finding Jesus, craaaazy message, book headache, pool & tacos & red dead sendoff, Spanish Thunderbolts, meeting a professor a few connections away from a Nobel Prize Winner, chivivi dog-like cat, killer gym-bro cabal, trespassing fruits, losing (the) will, commandeered billiards, fire-spitting power cord, coca-cola vacation tower.
-OTEGn5fv0XPafOQbzFM.title: Chaco Trees, Mute Carpenters, and a Mandioca Peeling Competition
